### R A First Look at Simulation

This section of the text introduces the concept of Monte Carlo simulation, along with some R commands using two examples (which are provided below or as script files). The first code starts with Example 1.32.

```{r example 1}
n <- 100 #set for example
sample(0:1, n, replace = TRUE)
mean(sample(0:1, n, replace = TRUE))
```

###Here are some of the functions that will be useful as we go through the course.

choose(n,k) - computes combination of choosing k objects from n.
prod(n:m) - computes the product of values from n to m. To do a permutation of r objects out of n,
you want to use prod(n:n-r+1). (For whatever reason, this doesnâ€™t work if you assign n and r first, just
put in the numbers).
factorial(x) - computes x!


```{r example 2}
choose(n = 10, k = 2)
## [1] 45
prod(8:6) # permutation of 3 objects out of 8
## [1] 336
factorial(x = 4)
##[1] 24
```
